snippet.title: Electricity And Circuits - Electric Cell and Torch Bulb - Science - Class 6
snippet.description:
An electric cell provides electricity to various devices that are not directly fed by the supply of electricity.

Electric Cell
An electric cell  consists of two terminals.  One is a positive terminal and the other one is a negative terminal.  A chemical that helps produce electricity to connected devices.

Bulb
A bulb consists two terminals.  A filament is a spirally wound wire inside the bulb supported by two thick wires at its ends. An electrical cell is connected to the terminals of a bulb so that electricity from the cell can pass through the bulb. This electricity makes the filament in the blub glow and emit light. Read more at https://www.learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VI-Science-Electric-Cell-and-Torch-Bulb.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Ratios and Proportions - Ratios - Maths - Class 6
snippet.description:
Usually, the comparison of quantities of the same type can be made by the method of difference between the quantities.    However, a more meaningful comparison between the quantities can be made by using division, i.e. by verifying how many times one quantity is into the other quantity.  This method is known as comparison by ratio.  Read more at https://www.learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VI-Maths-Ratios.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Fractions - Comparing Fractions - Maths - Class 6
snippet.description:
Fractions with the same denominator are called like fractions. 
Comparing like fractions: In like fractions, the fraction with the greater numerator is greater. 

Two fractions are unlike fractions if they have different denominators.

Comparing unlike fractions: If two fractions with the same numerator but different denominators are to be compared, then the fraction with the smaller denominator is the greater of the two.  

Read more at - https://www.learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VI-Maths-Comparing-Fractions.htm

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free
visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Acids, Bases and Salts - Indicators - Science - Class 6
snippet.description:
Many substances that you encounter in your daily life have different properties. One major difference between substances is whether they are acidic or basic. There are special substances that are used to test whether something is acidic or basic. These substances are called indicators.  Read more at - http://learnnext.com/lesson/CBSE-VII-Science-Indicators.htm

snippet.title: Class 6 | Maths | Algebra | Equations
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Maths | Algebra | Equations

In this module, you will learn to form equations using letters.
 
Anne wants to buy burgers, chocolate pastries, and fruit juices to serve at her brother’s birthday party.
She has a fixed budget of seven hundred and fifty rupees for eatables.
How many children can she invite to the party?
A burger costs 15 rupees, a chocolate pastry costs 20 rupees and a can of fruit juice costs 15 rupees.
Thus, the total cost of eatables for one child will be 50 rupees. The cost for two children will be 100 rupees, for three children will be 150 rupees, and so on.
Let’s assume that the number of children attending the party is n. 
The total amount required for the eatables will be 50 multiplied by n rupees.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 6 | Maths | Fractions | Comparing Fractions
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Maths | Fractions | Comparing Fractions

In this module, you will learn to compare like fractions.
Here are three candy boxes that are divided into six equal parts.
The first box has one-sixth candies, the second box has three-sixth candies in it and the third has five-sixth candies in it.
The denominators of all three fractions are the same.
Such fractions are called like fractions.
Fractions having the same denominator are called like fractions.
Of the three fractions, we can see that one-sixth is smaller than three-sixth and three-sixth is smaller that five-sixth.
Like fractions can be compared by comparing their numerators.
The fraction with a smaller numerator will have a smaller value compared to the fraction with a greater numerator.
Now let’s consider another example. There are two, three by four boxes of red marbles,  and three, one by four boxes of green marbles.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 6 | Maths | Symmetry | Mirror Symmetry
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Maths | Symmetry | Mirror Symmetry 

In this module, you will learn how to create symmetrical patterns.

One half of a figure along with its line of symmetry is given. 
Let us see how we can create the other half with the help of the line of symmetry.
We will use a squared paper to complete this figure.

We have to consider each part of the given figure and draw its corresponding part on the other side of the line of symmetry.
For example, the horizontal line in the given figure extends for a width of two squares on the squared paper from the line of symmetry. 
So, we draw a similar line to the left of the given line of symmetry, as shown.
Next, look at the slanting line in the given figure. 
The slanting line is a diagonal of the third square to the right of the line of symmetry.
So, we draw a similar line to the left of the given line of symmetry, as shown.
This completes the given figure along the vertical line of symmetry. 
Note that each part of the constructed figure is equal in measurement to its corresponding part.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

snippet.title: Class 6 | Science | Body Movements | Bones and Skeleton
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Science | Body Movements | Bones and Skeleton

In this module, you will learn about bones and skeleton.


What are the different bones of the body?

The skeleton is made up of several bones that include the skull, arm bone, leg bone, shoulder bone, rib cage, hip bones, backbone and cartilage. Each bone is in turn made of many bones.  
For example, the skull found in the head is made up of many bones and protects the brain against any injury.
 
What are the bones of the arms and legs?
The arm bone consists of the humerus, radius, ulna, carpals, metacarpals and phalanges. 
There are several tiny bones that form the palm, wrist and fingers of the hand. 
The arm enables the body to perform many important functions. 


To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 6 | Science | Components of food | Deficiency Diseases
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Science | Components of food | Deficiency Diseases  


Is it possible to get all the nutrients from a single food item?
A single food item cannot contain all the nutrients.
Wheat, for instance, is rich in carbohydrates but lacks nutrients like proteins and fats.
So, if we just eat wheat products, our body will not get all the nutrients required for healthy growth.
If this continues for a long time, we may suffer from a deficiency of nutrients like proteins and fats.

Thus, deficiency of one or more nutrients for a long period may lead to disorders or diseases called deficiency diseases.
What impact do deficiency diseases have on children?
Children 
require a lot of proteins for their growth. Lack of proteins in their diet may cause stunted growth, swelling of the face, discolouration of hair, skin diseases and diarrhoea.
Similarly, lack of proteins and carbohydrates can halt their growth completely and make them thin and weak ...

To watch more Class 6 Science Videos.
Visit: https://www.learnnext.com/CBSE/Class-6/Science/Biology/Components-of-Food/Deficiency-Diseases/L-2842.htm#container

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

snippet.title: Class 6 | Science | Separation of Substances | Methods of Separation
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Science | Separation of Substances | Methods of Separation

In this module, you will learn about the separation of substances under dry conditions.
Handpicking is the basic method for separation of substances.
It involves simply picking out substances by hand and separating them from others.
The substances being separated may be impurities that have to be thrown away.
Or it may be that both the substances being separated are useful – such as if you separate green grapes from black ones from a mixture of the two.
There are other alternative methods to separate substances such as threshing.
This is done after harvesting of crops.
Once wheat is harvested, the stalks are dried.
Then, each grain of wheat is separated from the stalks to which it is attached so that it can be ground into flour.
This method of separating grains from stalks is called threshing.
It is basically the beating of these dry stalks to shake off the dried grains.
It can be done by hand, by cattle, or by using machines.
Traditionally, threshing was done by hand, but cattle help to do this job quickly.
Nowadays, threshing machines are also used to separate large quantities of grain at a time.
One of these machines is a combine harvester.

To watch more Class 6 Science Videos.
Visit: https://www.learnnext.com/CBSE/Class-6/Science/Chemistry/Separation-of-Substances/Methods-of-Separation-I/L-2832.htm#container

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

snippet.title: Class 6 | Maths | Algebra Use Of Variable | Use of Variable
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Maths | Algebra Use Of Variable | Use of Variable

Consider a weighing scale. One pan has four kilograms weight in it and the other has two kilograms.

To balance the scale, two kilograms are added to the left pan and four kilograms are added to the right pan.
Now, the scale is balanced. This means that the sum of four and two kilograms is equal to the sum of two and four kilograms, which is equal to six kilograms. 

In this module, you will learn to frame rules from arithmetic.

Let’s look at another example. The right pan has five kilograms and the left pan has three kilograms.
To balance the scale, three kilograms are added to the right pan and five kilograms to the left pan. 
This means that the sum of three and five kilograms is equal to the sum of five and three kilograms, which is equal to eight kilograms. 
This property of numbers is called commutativity of addition.

snippet.title: Class 6 | Maths | Fractions Addition and Subtraction of Fractions
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Maths | Fractions Addition and Subtraction of Fractions 

In this module, you will learn how to add and subtract fractions.

There are two cans of milk. There is 1 to 5 litres of milk in one and 2 to 5 litres of milk in the second. 
What is the total quantity of milk
Both these fractions have the same number in the denominator, so they are like fractions.
When two like fractions are added, their sum will be a fraction with the same denominator.
So, here the denominator of the sum will also be 5.
The numerator of the sum will be equal to the sum of the numerators of the fraction.
Here, we will add the numerators 1 and 2. We get 3, which is the numerator of the sum.
Now use the common denominator of the like fractions as the denominator in the resultant fraction. 
Here, the denominator is five.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 6 | Science | Body Movements | Gait of Animals
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Science | Body Movements | Gait of Animals

In this module, you will learn about the gait of animals.

The body movements are possible in humans because of several bones and joints. Let us see how the movement takes place in some of the smaller animals.
 
How does an earthworm move?

Earthworm’s body secretes a slimy substance that helps it to move. The tiny stiff hair-like projections, called bristles, under their body help them to grab the soil. 
They first stretch out and then contract the muscles to move. 
They draw out the front part of their body, keeping the back fixed to the ground. And, then they release the back portion keeping the front part fixed. Hence, they cover only a small distance with every move.
They can move with ease on a hard and slippery surface.
.The intestine throws away undigested matter as small pellets into the soil. This improves the quality of the soil for plants.
Animation/Graphic Type: 2D/3D

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 6 | Science | Components of Food | Nutrients and Balanced Diet
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Science | Components of Food | Nutrients and Balanced Diet

In this module, you will learn about the importance of carbohydrates, fats and proteins.
Carbohydrates provide energy to perform various body activities such as walking, running and breathing.
What are the sources of carbohydrates?
The carbohydrate-rich foods include wheat, rice, potato, sugarcane, mango, watermelon and bananas.

What do fats do in our body?

Fats provide energy similar to carbohydrates.
In fact, they provide double the energy compared to carbohydrates.
Hence, fats, along with carbohydrates, are called ‘energy giving foods’.
Fats are deposited underneath our skin and around the internal organs.
 They prevent rapid loss of heat from our body to the surroundings thereby maintaining the normal temperature of the body.

To watch the complete lesson, register to get 5-day full access for free

visit - http://bit.ly/2KbImVd

snippet.title: Class 6 | Science | Separation of Substances | Methods of Separation
snippet.description:
Class 6 | Science | Separation of Substances | Methods of Separation

In this module, you will learn about the methods of separation of substances under wet conditions.
Sedimentation and Decantation 
Even liquids that do not mix with each other can be separated by the processes of sedimentation and decantation.
For example, water and oil.
Water is heavier than oil, so it settles at the bottom if you leave it alone for some time.
Once the water settles at the bottom, the oil can be seen floating on top.
Then, the oil can simply be poured out of the beaker.

Filtration 
Now, let’s see how dirty water can be cleaned.
Dirty water can be completely cleaned using a filter paper.
This process of using a filter to separate substances is called filtration.
This will work as long as the holes or pores of the filter are small enough to keep the larger substances and let the smaller substances pass through.
